params.name: target
params.description: A target object or a function

params.name: method
params.description: A function or the name of a function to be called on `target`

params.name: once
params.description: A flag whether a function should only be called once

@ember/object/events.description:
Remove an event listener

Arguments should match those passed to `addListener`.
@ember/object/events.name: removeListener

params.name: target
params.description: A target object or a function

params.name: method
params.description: A function or the name of a function to be called on `target`

@ember/object/events.description:
Send an event. The execution of suspended listeners
is skipped, and once listeners are removed. A listener without
a target is executed on the passed object. If an array of actions
is not passed, the actions stored on the passed object are invoked.
@ember/object/events.name: sendEvent

params.name: params
params.description: Optional parameters for each listener.

return.description: true

@ember/object/computed.name: alias

return.description:
computed property which creates an
alias to the original value for property.

@ember/object/computed.name: and

return.description:
computed property which performs
a logical `and` on the values of all the original values for properties.

@ember/object/computed.name: bool

return.description:
computed property which converts
to boolean the original value for property

@ember/object/computed.name: collect

return.description:
computed property which maps
values of all passed in properties to an array.

@ember/object/computed.name: deprecatingAlias

params.name: options
params.description: Options for `deprecate`.

return.description:
computed property which creates an
alias with a deprecation to the original value for property.

@ember/object/computed.name: empty

return.description:
computed property which returns true if
the value of the dependent property is null, an empty string, empty array,
or empty function and false if the underlying value is not empty.

@ember/object/computed.name: equal

return.description:
computed property which returns true if
the original value for property is equal to the given value.

@ember/object/computed.description:
Expands `pattern`, invoking `callback` for each expansion.

The only pattern supported is brace-expansion, anything else will be passed
once to `callback` directly.

Example

```js
import { expandProperties } from '@ember/object/computed';

function echo(arg){ console.log(arg); }

expandProperties('foo.bar', echo);              //=> 'foo.bar'
expandProperties('{foo,bar}', echo);            //=> 'foo', 'bar'
expandProperties('foo.{bar,baz}', echo);        //=> 'foo.bar', 'foo.baz'
expandProperties('{foo,bar}.baz', echo);        //=> 'foo.baz', 'bar.baz'
expandProperties('foo.{bar,baz}.[]', echo)      //=> 'foo.bar.[]', 'foo.baz.[]'
expandProperties('{foo,bar}.{spam,eggs}', echo) //=> 'foo.spam', 'foo.eggs', 'bar.spam', 'bar.eggs'
expandProperties('{foo}.bar.{baz}')             //=> 'foo.bar.baz'
```
@ember/object/computed.name: expandProperties

params.name: pattern
params.description: The property pattern to expand.

params.name: callback
params.description:
The callback to invoke.  It is invoked once per
expansion, and is passed the expansion.

@ember/object/computed.name: filter

return.description: the filtered array

@ember/object/computed.name: filterBy

return.description: the filtered array

@ember/object/computed.name: gt

return.description:
computed property which returns true if
the original value for property is greater than given value.

@ember/object/computed.name: gte

return.description:
computed property which returns true if
the original value for property is greater or equal then given value.

@ember/object/computed.name: intersect

return.description:
computes a new array with all the
duplicated elements from the dependent arrays

@ember/object/computed.name: lt

return.description:
computed property which returns true if
the original value for property is less then given value.

@ember/object/computed.name: lte

return.description:
computed property which returns true if
the original value for property is less or equal than given value.

@ember/object/computed.name: map

return.description: an array mapped via the callback

@ember/object/computed.name: mapBy

return.description: an array mapped to the specified key

@ember/object/computed.name: match

return.description:
computed property which match
the original value for property against a given RegExp

@ember/object/computed.name: max

return.description: computes the largest value in the dependentKey's array

@ember/object/computed.name: min

return.description: computes the smallest value in the dependentKey's array

@ember/object/computed.name: none

return.description:
computed property which
returns true if original value for property is null or undefined.

@ember/object/computed.name: not

return.description:
computed property which returns
inverse of the original value for property

@ember/object/computed.name: notEmpty

return.description:
computed property which returns true if
original value for property is not empty.

@ember/object/computed.name: oneWay

return.description:
computed property which creates a
one way computed property to the original value for property.

@ember/object/computed.name: or

return.description:
computed property which performs
a logical `or` on the values of all the original values for properties.

@ember/object/computed.name: readOnly

return.description:
computed property which creates a
one way computed property to the original value for property.

@ember/object/computed.description:
This is a more semantically meaningful alias of `computed.oneWay`,
whose name is somewhat ambiguous as to which direction the data flows.
@ember/object/computed.name: reads

return.description:
computed property which creates a
  one way computed property to the original value for property.

@ember/object/computed.name: setDiff

return.description:
computes a new array with all the
items from the first dependent array that are not in the second
dependent array

computes a new array with all the

computes a new array with all the

@ember/object.description:
Gets the value of a property on an object. If the property is computed,
the function will be invoked. If the property is not defined but the
object implements the `unknownProperty` method then that will be invoked.

```javascript
import { get } from '@ember/object';
get(obj, "name");
```

If you plan to run on IE8 and older browsers then you should use this
method anytime you want to retrieve a property on an object that you don't
know for sure is private. (Properties beginning with an underscore '_'
are considered private.)

On all newer browsers, you only need to use this method to retrieve
properties if the property might not be defined on the object and you want
to respect the `unknownProperty` handler. Otherwise you can ignore this
method.

Note that if the object itself is `undefined`, this method will throw
an error.
@ember/object.name: get

params.name: obj
params.description: The object to retrieve from.

params.name: keyName
params.description: The property key to retrieve

return.description: the property value or `null`.

@ember/object.name: getProperties

params.name: list
params.description: of keys to get

@ember/object.name: getWithDefault

params.name: obj
params.description: The object to retrieve from.

params.name: keyName
params.description: The name of the property to retrieve

params.name: defaultValue
params.description: The value to return if the property value is undefined

return.description: The property value or the defaultValue.

@ember/object.name: observer

return.description: func

@ember/object.name: reopen
reopenClass

@ember/object.description:
Sets the value of a property on an object, respecting computed properties
and notifying observers and other listeners of the change.
If the specified property is not defined on the object and the object
implements the `setUnknownProperty` method, then instead of setting the
value of the property on the object, its `setUnknownProperty` handler
will be invoked with the two parameters `keyName` and `value`.

```javascript
import { set } from '@ember/object';
set(obj, "name", value);
```
@ember/object.name: set

params.name: obj
params.description: The object to modify.

params.name: keyName
params.description: The property key to set

params.name: value
params.description: The value to set

return.description: the passed value.

@ember/object.name: setProperties

return.description: properties

@ember/object.name: trySet

params.name: root
params.description: The object to modify.

params.name: path
params.description: The property path to set

params.name: value
params.description: The value to set

@ember/object/internals.description:
Returns the cached value for a property, if one exists.
This can be useful for peeking at the value of a computed
property that is generated lazily, without accidentally causing
it to be created.
@ember/object/internals.name: cacheFor

params.name: obj
params.description: the object whose property you want to check

params.name: key
params.description:
the name of the property whose cached value you want
  to return

return.description: the cached value

@ember/object/internals.description:
Creates a shallow copy of the passed object. A deep copy of the object is
returned if the optional `deep` argument is `true`.

If the passed object implements the `Copyable` interface, then this
function will delegate to the object's `copy()` method and return the
result. See `Copyable` for further details.

For primitive values (which are immutable in JavaScript), the passed object
is simply returned.
@ember/object/internals.name: copy

params.name: obj
params.description: The object to clone

params.name: deep
params.description: If true, a deep copy of the object is made.

return.description: The copied object

@ember/object/internals.description:
Returns a unique id for the object. If the object does not yet have a guid,
one will be assigned to it. You can call this on any object,
`EmberObject`-based or not.

You can also use this method on DOM Element objects.
@ember/object/internals.name: guidFor

params.name: obj
params.description: any object, string, number, Element, or primitive

return.description: the unique guid for this instance.

@ember/object.description:
Gets the value of a property on an object. If the property is computed,
the function will be invoked. If the property is not defined but the
object implements the `unknownProperty` method then that will be invoked.

```javascript
import { get } from '@ember/object';
get(obj, "name");
```

If you plan to run on IE8 and older browsers then you should use this
method anytime you want to retrieve a property on an object that you don't
know for sure is private. (Properties beginning with an underscore '_'
are considered private.)

On all newer browsers, you only need to use this method to retrieve
properties if the property might not be defined on the object and you want
to respect the `unknownProperty` handler. Otherwise you can ignore this
method.

Note that if the object itself is `undefined`, this method will throw
an error.
@ember/object.name: get

params.name: obj
params.description: The object to retrieve from.

params.name: keyName
params.description: The property key to retrieve

return.description: the property value or `null`.

@ember/object.name: getProperties

params.name: list
params.description: of keys to get

params.name: obj
params.description: The object to retrieve from.

params.name: keyName
params.description: The name of the property to retrieve

params.name: defaultValue
params.description: The value to return if the property value is undefined

return.description: The property value or the defaultValue.

implements the `setUnknownProperty` method, then instead of setting the
value of the property on the object, its `setUnknownProperty` handler
will be invoked with the two parameters `keyName` and `value`.

```javascript
import { set } from '@ember/object';
set(obj, "name", value);
```

Creates a shallow copy of the passed object. A deep copy of the object is
returned if the optional `deep` argument is `true`.

If the passed object implements the `Copyable` interface, then this
function will delegate to the object's `copy()` method and return the
result. See `Copyable` for further details.

For primitive values (which are immutable in JavaScript), the passed object
is simply returned.

@ember/object/internals.description:
Generates a new guid, optionally saving the guid to the object that you
pass in. You will rarely need to use this method. Instead you should
call `guidFor(obj)`, which return an existing guid if available.
@ember/object/internals.name: generateGuid

params.name: obj
params.description:
Object the guid will be used for. If passed in, the guid will
  be saved on the object and reused whenever you pass the same object
  again.

  If no object is passed, just generate a new guid.

params.name: prefix
params.description:
Prefix to place in front of the guid. Useful when you want to
  separate the guid into separate namespaces.

return.description: the guid

@ember/object/internals.description:
Returns a unique id for the object. If the object does not yet have a guid,
one will be assigned to it. You can call this on any object,
`EmberObject`-based or not.

You can also use this method on DOM Element objects.
@ember/object/internals.name: guidFor

params.name: obj
params.description: any object, string, number, Element, or primitive

return.description: the unique guid for this instance.
